articles.headline: Dolan Chosen as President of U.S. Bishops’ Group
articles.snippet: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York will lead the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.
articles.abstract: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York will lead the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE  The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops elected Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York to be its president on Tuesday in a surprise move that reaffirmed the conservative direction of the Roman Catholic Church in America.

articles.headline: Boeing and Airbus Waver on Reworking Their Smaller Jets
articles.snippet: Airlines want more fuel-efficient versions of the 737 and A320, but the planes’ makers are looking to new aircraft.
articles.abstract: Airlines want more fuel-efficient versions of the 737 and A320, but the planes’ makers are looking to new aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest high-stakes maneuvering by Boeing and Airbus does not involve their top-of-the-line models, the 787 Dreamliner and the A380 jumbo jet, but instead their aging smaller workhorses.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Currency Fight With China Divides U.S. Business
articles.snippet: American businesses that import Chinese goods face higher prices, but exporters are predicting sales growth.
articles.abstract: American businesses that import Chinese goods face higher prices, but exporters are predicting sales growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHUJI, China  For American business, the United States currency dispute with China is a two-sided coin.

articles.headline: In the Heartland, Still Investing in Coal
articles.snippet: Despite calls to cut greenhouse gases, numerous coal plants under construction today are likely to be pumping out carbon dioxide until at least 2050.
articles.abstract: Despite calls to cut greenhouse gases, numerous coal plants under construction today are likely to be pumping out carbon dioxide until at least 2050.

articles.headline: There Will Be Fuel
articles.snippet: Recent discoveries of oil and natural gas fields and new mining technology have combined to help increase the world’s supply of energy for decades to come.
articles.abstract: Recent discoveries of oil and natural gas fields and new mining technology have combined to help increase the world’s supply of energy for decades to come.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Panel Backs Drug for Lupus
articles.snippet: Benlysta would be the first approved drug to treat lupus in decades.
articles.abstract: Benlysta would be the first approved drug to treat lupus in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: What could become the first new drug approved to treat lupus in more than half a century moved a big step closer to the market on Tuesday by winning an endorsement from a federal advisory committee.

articles.headline: A New G.M., but Not an End to the Bailout Era
articles.snippet: General Motors’ stock offering is a milestone, but Washington is still contending with other costly rescues.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ stock offering is a milestone, but Washington is still contending with other costly rescues.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the bailout, now comes the bail-in.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: New Push for Ireland to Consent to a Bailout
articles.snippet: European finance ministers met in Brussels Tuesday to pressure a reluctant Ireland to accept an $80 billion financial rescue plan.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers met in Brussels Tuesday to pressure a reluctant Ireland to accept an $80 billion financial rescue plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Ireland tried to fend off pressure to accept a bailout on Tuesday and other European nations raised objections to participating in a rescue plan, Europe again found itself confronting a crisis of confidence in the euro and, ultimately, in its ability to manage its economic problems.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and James Kanter

articles.headline: G.O.P. Opposition Dims Hope for Arms Treaty With Russia
articles.snippet: The chief Senate Republican negotiator dealt a setback to President Obama’s effort to pass a treaty with Russia.
articles.abstract: The chief Senate Republican negotiator dealt a setback to President Obama’s effort to pass a treaty with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s hopes of ratifying a new arms control treaty with Russia by the end of the year appeared to come undone on Tuesday as the chief Senate Republican negotiator moved to block a vote on the pact, one of the White House’s top foreign policy goals, in the lame-duck session of Congress.

articles.headline: NATO Is Razing Booby-Trapped Afghan Homes
articles.snippet: The campaign in districts abandoned by the Taliban is meant to reduce casualties but is drawing complaints.
articles.abstract: The campaign in districts abandoned by the Taliban is meant to reduce casualties but is drawing complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  In the newly won districts around this southern city, American forces are encountering empty homes and farm buildings left so heavily booby-trapped by Taliban insurgents that the Americans have been systematically destroying hundreds of them, according to local Afghan authorities.
articles.byline: By Taimoor Shah and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: One Way to Trim Deficit: Cultivate Growth
articles.snippet: Economic growth, if it is not cut, would go a long way toward reducing the deficit.
articles.abstract: Economic growth, if it is not cut, would go a long way toward reducing the deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: We look back on the late 1990s as a rare time when the federal government ran budget surpluses. We tend to forget that those surpluses came as a surprise to almost everybody.

articles.headline: Beijing’s Focus on Food Prices Ignores Broader Inflation Risk
articles.snippet: Chinese policy makers are striving to curb inflation, but their approach carries risks. For one thing, their plan flies in the face of steps the U.S. has been urging.
articles.abstract: Chinese policy makers are striving to curb inflation, but their approach carries risks. For one thing, their plan flies in the face of steps the U.S. has been urging.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  China took steps Wednesday to control rising prices at the most basic consumer level. But Beijing faces a severe challenge in preventing higher global commodity prices from igniting broader inflation that could threaten China’s streak of powerful economic growth.
